step.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the movement you make when you put one foot in front of or behind the other when walking
step.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: a video of baby’s first steps
He took one step and fell.
I had to retrace my steps (=go back the way I came) several times before I found the shop.
Tom took a step back and held the door open.
step.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: one of a series of things that you do in order to deal with a problem or to succeed
step.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: This is the first step in reforming the welfare system.
The president took immediate steps to stop the fighting.
step.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a stage in a process, or a position on a scale
step.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Each book goes up one step in difficulty.
Record your result, and go on to step 3.
Drug companies influence the scientific process every step of the way (=during every stage).
Describe step by step (=describing each stage) how you went about achieving your goal.
Moving to Cottage Grove represented a definite step up (=something that is better than you had before) for my parents.
He saw the job as a step down (=something that is worse than he had before).
the next step in the process
step.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a flat narrow piece of wood or stone, especially one in a series, that you put your foot on when you are going up or down, especially outside a building
step.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Jenny sat on the step in front of the house, waiting.
He climbed the wooden steps and rang the bell.
a flight of (=set of) broad stone  steps
step.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the short distance you move when you take a step while walking
step.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Roy was standing only a few steps away.
step.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: the sound you make when you put your foot down while walking
step.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I heard a step in the corridor.
step.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: a movement of your feet in dancing
step.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: the way someone walks, which often tells you how they are feeling
step.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: a type of exercise you do by walking onto and off a flat piece of equipment around 15–30 centimetres  high
step.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: the difference in pitch between two musical notes that are separated by one key on the piano
step.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 2: one of a series of things that you do in order to deal with a problem or to succeed
step.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: take a step
The authority will take steps to reunite the child and his family.
an important/major/big step
The move is seen as a major step forward for UK firms.
the first step
The first step in resolving conflict is to understand what the other person wants.
the next step
He met in Washington with his campaign advisers to plan his next step.
a small step
This is a small step in the right direction.
a positive step
This is a positive step which gives cause for some optimism.
an unusual/unprecedented step
Police last night took the unusual step of releasing photographs of him.
a drastic step
The government is wary of taking any drastic steps that would scare off foreign investment.
a bold step
We welcome the bold step taken by President Bush.
a tentative step
The Institute has taken a tentative step towards opening up its meetings to the public.
a logical step
She felt she had an aptitude for medicine. Her next logical step would be to begin studying when the summer was over.
immediate steps
We believe immediate steps could be taken to generate jobs.
reasonable steps
They must take reasonable steps to ensure that this information is available to those who might benefit.
necessary steps
We must be sure that we are taking the necessary steps to prevent the problem from getting a foothold here.
a step forward
The declaration which we have just signed is a big step forward for both of our nations.
a step backwards/a backward step
A rationing system would be a major step backwards.
a step in the right direction
Environmentalists said the law was a step in the right direction.
step.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to raise one foot and put it down in front of or behind the other one in order to walk or move
step.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Mr Ives? Please step this way (=walk in the direction I am showing you).
He stepped back to let me through.
I stepped outside and closed the door.
step.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to bring your foot down on something
step.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I accidentally stepped in a puddle.
step.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: used to show that someone is related to you not by birth but because a parent has married again
step.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: one of a series of things that you do to deal with a problem or to succeed
step.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The changes are only the first step in a long-term plan.
Japan took steps to boost confidence in its tumbling stock market.
Sweeping reforms were announced in a step towards a free-market economy.
step.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: a stage in a process or a position on a scale
step.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Every year you go up one step on the salary scale.
I’ve taken the first step on the managerial ladder.
Nina’s promotion is quite a step up for one so young.
step.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: if people, organizations etc are out of step, their ideas, actions etc are different from other people’s, especially because they are old-fashioned
step.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The fast food chain has been out of step with consumers’ changing eating patterns in recent years.
step.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: to be better prepared or know more about something
step.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: In business, you need to be one step ahead of your competitors.
